title: Electron Microscopic Analysis of Rotating Single Lattice ZnO Crystals Produced by Photothermal Laser Printing
content: Multi-photon 3D laser printing of polymers is a widely used technology for manufacturing complex structures at the micro- and nanoscale [1, 2]. A laser is focused into a liquid ink, triggering a reaction that solidifies the ink. Besides polymers, recent efforts focus on the printing of non-organic materials. However, the latter usually require post-processing steps at high temperatures, limiting the use of multi-material architectures since high temperatures affect the polymer structure [3]. Recent advancements in direct printing of semiconducting ZnO using hydrothermal synthesis have allowed for direct laser printing of functional microelectronic devices without post-processing [3]. However, the presence of water in the ink leads to severe bubble formation during laser heating due to the relatively low boiling point of water (100 °C). The current study explores an alternative approach using dimethyl sulfoxid (DMSO, boiling point of 189 °C) for photothermal printing of ZnO crystals with sub-µm feature sizes. Using electron microscopy, we demonstrate that single crystalline ZnO can be printed on amorphous substrates, opening the possibility of new applications, e.g., printed piezoelectric devices. Still, a better understanding of the growth of the ZnO crystals is required for improved control over the fabrication of the printed structures and their electronic properties.
